comments.text: Thank you so much for sharing your design! It printed perfectly, and the switch + plug holes are in the best locations possible. It fit very well over the power supply. I just had to make a hole in the metal to be able to insert another screw. The only issue I dealt with was if you routed the wires through the hole in the frame of the printer under the power supply. It didn't allow room for the cover, so I snipped a little plastic from the bottom of the cover. and that helped. Other than that, awesome work.

author: Nybyaday

title: CCG deck box with geared pivoting lid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: There are some excellent deck boxes on thingiverse, but I thought, you know... they aren't complex and pointless enough. So in the spirit of the game of thrones intro map thingy I thought I'd add some gears and a rack and pinion lift system and a couple of other nifty things. Here it is in action. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Z8l1qjhh3E

There's quite a few moving parts to this one. You'll need to print one of each of the 8 STL files. The scad file uses the printable rack ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11642 ) by devijvers and of course the ubiquitous involute gear library ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575 ) by Greg Frost. At the moment I haven't glued anything, it's just pressed together. The SCAD file includes a parameter for printing tolerance currently set to 0.2mm. It's likely your printer is better tuned than mine, so you may not need it. The scad file is (theoretically) fully parametric and has instructions on how to change (for example) the x, y and z dimensions of the cards and a heap of other values. A couple of the attached images show how the box is put together. The main things are:
1) The two sets of top (rotating sections) are connected by a plastic "key" (little oblongs of plastic) to hold them together.
2) put the "lift platform" into the two rack sections and put the racks in place before mounting the top sections. You need to make sure the teeth of the gears and the rack are nice and clean and mesh well.
3) There are 6 hinges that allow the side pieces to move outwards when the tops are rotated. I used dressmakers pins as the axles for those hinges. Cut the heads off them and push them through and bend each end over so they stay in place. There's probably a better solution, but because my printers not so well tuned, the pins were a firm fit and worked well. Oh also, two of the stls wouldn't slice properly with slicr (3 and 6) but they did slice ok with skeinforge. Update: Added a base, updated SCAD file to reflect this, updated "full exploded" image to include the new base. (deck_box_8.stl) Update 2: I changed the name from 'unnecessarily complex mtg deck box' because it wasn't clear to a number of people that 'unnecessarily complex' was supposed to denote the over-the-top design idea rather than the construction. And of course it can be used for any ccg not just mtg.

comments.text: Layout 6 shouldn't have anything to do with the rack library at all as far as I can tell. At least none of the coding refers to it. The problem, from what I can tell is that the cylinder's hole cutout go from exactly the end of one side of the cylinder to exactly the other end of the cylinder so that it creates this 2-manifold error. Meaning when you put a hole in an object you want it to extend past both ends of the object. If that makes sense.

comments.text: Your mileage may vary, eg it depends on whether you sleeve and how thick your sleeves are. Best to measure your cards - the space is 30mm and it's best if the cards aren't in too tight. Having said that, the SCAD file is there and it's pretty straightforward to modify this value to make it more than 30mm.
comments.author: knightofgold

comments.text: While it looks amazing, I cannot recommend making it. It takes hours to print and especially the sides of the box is impossible to assemble. And then you realize, when it's almost done, that you can't use it because it doesn't fit 60 cards in deck protectors! If you want to use this for any kind of play involving protectors you'll need to modify the SCAD files. However do be aware that according to the comments that some of the dimensions are fudged so do so at your own risk.

author: luisvillamolo

title: Bubo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This owl is inspired by Bubo, from the movies "Clash of the Titans" (wiki)

First moves:
-YouTube 1
-YouTube 2

"Finished" item:

-YouTube 3

Todo:

  • Maybe improve software GitHub
  • Complete instructions
  • Collect tips :)

Non printed items:

  • Arduino Nano/Pro Mini
  • DF-Player AliExpress
  • Gyro GY-521 MPU6050 AliExpress (Not really used, yet)
  • Boost Converter AliExpress + FET
  • H-Bridge Motor driver AliExpress
  • 2x PCB AliExpress
  • Wire AliExpress
  • Solenoid AliExpress
  • 3x Small Servo AliExpress
  • 1x Big Servo AliExpress
  • 2x Ball Bearings MR105ZZ (eyes)
  • 7x Ball Bearings 6700ZZ (2x eyes , 1x head , 4x wings)
  • 2x Ball Bearings 625ZZ Legs
  • 2 Neopixels AliExpress
  • Optic Fiber AliExpress
  • 2x Geared motor AliExpress
  • 2x M4 rods ( For inside the legs )
  • M2 Bolts and nuts
  • M2 Brass Knurled Nuts Aliexpress
  • M3 Bolts and nuts
  • M2 Brass Knurled Nuts Aliexpress

Additional tools:

  • Hotglue
  • Heatgun (I use this one: AliExpress)

Feathers

All "Feather" parts should be printed in PLA and the "Shell" parts in PETG/ABS.
Then you can shape the feathers around the shell using a heatgun.
To get the "BodyFeaters" to fit better, you can scale (x-only) it in your slicer.

I have updated the schematic. It does not include the gyro-board but that also isn't used in the software (yet?).
The way I have connected the DF-Player is so that you have to disconnect it to upload a new sketch. That is why I put the DF-Player in the tail, so I can easily disconnect it and have access to the SD-Card. I have used a IRLB8721 MOSFET to switch the DC-DC converter. The output of the converter should bet set to 12V.

author: doodady

remixed_from.author: FollowMeOn
remixed_from.title: Dual Mode Spring Motor Rolling Chassis

title: Remix of Dual Mode Spring Motor Rolling Chassis

description.text:
I really liked this design that Greg Zumwalt made. I started off just redesigning the rear wheels so I could use the #222 O-Rings from http://www.harborfreight.com/382-piece-o-ring-assortment-67554.html since this o-ring set did not have the #223 size. Initially I thought the wheels might be too complex for me to modify, but they turned out to lend themselves well to modifying. After printing a couple of the smaller gears, my printer had problems printing to these tight tolerances. I decided to modify the parts that I wanted to change the tolerances on. The gearing took the most effort for me since I am not familiar with designing gears. Fortunally I found this cool openscad script http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5505 that made it rather easy to create the gear changes I needed.

I made several rear wheel versions using #222 & #325 O-rings and for the front wheels #213 & #214. In the file name the number following OR (OR222) defines the o-ring used and the 1x,2x,3x or 4x defines how many o-rings per wheel are used. I have not printed all the iterations of these. If you need another size or I miscalculated something, let me know & I will try to accomodate.

I printed these using eSun Silver PLA+ at 20% infill, .2mm height with a .4mm nozzle. Slicing was with slic3r 1.2.9. Printing took about 12 hours & used 3.9oz of plasitc.

My 1st test crank of this vehicle did not work well. All I needed to do was sand a little more where the large idler gear connected. The wheels also come off sometimes, so I am going to super glue them on now that everything seems to be working ok.

If you want to avoid more sanding like I do, I made a version of the Idler_Small & that axle combined (Gear_Idler_Small_And_Axle_Mod_Rev11.stl) as well as the Rear axle & that gear combined (Gear_And_Axle_Rear_Mod_Rev11.stl). I added 4mm to the height of the idler axle. I just printed the Gear_And_Axle_Rear & it looks pretty good. You will have to print these with supports, but the gears are small so not that much support needed.

I included the openscad files & STL files so you can change any hole or shaft sizes that do not work for you.

For further info & assembly instructions of this see the original design of this part: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2025760

comments.text: Congratulations, very good work!  Looks great also!
comments.author: FollowMeOn

comments.text: Thanks for releasing a cool design to play with.

title: Fidget Spinner(1x608 skateboard bearing + 6x0.05 euro cents as weights)

description.text:
Hi
This is my first Fidget Spinner published to thingiverse. I tried to make something different because everyone has at least 1 bearing laying around. And in europe almost everyon uses euros so everyone has a couple of 0.05 euro cents laying around.

It is printed in 2 halves to insert the 0.05 cents.

Feel free to ask anything. I would love to make changes if any of you have improvements or ideas?

Have fun spinning!

Printer:

P802Q

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100% (Own preference)

Notes:

Don't use a brim for a better look(no edges after gluing together

How to put it together:

-Remove supports and use sandpaper to make everything nice and smooth especially the edges from the bottom.
-Add the bearing, It is a tight fit so maybe you should use a hammer or stand on it.
-Now put in the 5 cents,1-3 on top of each other(i prefer 2) to add weight.
-put glue on all the edges(I use superglue) and put the other half on top.
-wait untill the glue is dry and maybe use sandpaper to smoothen everything up again.
-put in the axle holders(if loose glue them in place).

----See pictures----
Happy spinning!

I was bored playing with my fidget spinner...

Then I opened up solidworks and started making my own fidget spinner. Now 3 designs later I came with this idea. Instead of using 4 bearings I tried using a couple of 0.05 euro cents as weight. saves money(by using money?????) with the same result.

description.text:
January 12 & 16

I did a little work on the Grasshopper definition for the Twisted Bead. This is a little more suitable for making vases. Just draw the driving curves, move the base point to control scale, and set the amount of twist and the number of surface texture repeats. I usually work in Rhino to tweak the form generated by the Grasshopper definition. The CageEdit command is good to adjust the overall form quickly. That's how I shaped the elliptical opening at the top.

The STL is meant to be sliced with "spiral vase" mode (or just omit infill and top layers).

This is for Pittsburgh's Fun a Day, 2017.

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Resolution:

0.5mm

Infill:

None

Notes:

Printed with a 1.0mm nozzle using natural ABS. I used 4 solid bottom layers and printed s_l_o_w_l_y (20mm/s).

Update: The model contracted a little more than expected, uploaded an updated file with slightly wider openings to fit the relays. My apologies!

Needed a way to mount multiple 12V automotive relays in my engine bay and keep them clean. This holds six (6) standard automotive relays that are approximately 1x1.125x1".

I'll update the model as I make improvements to it.

Cheers!

title: Union Jack - United Kingdom / Great Britain Flag

description.text:
With 2012 being the year of the London Olympics and the Queen's Diamond Jubilee, the Union Jack seemed an appropriate project to try out some multicoloured printing on my RepRapPro - single extruder - Huxley.
RichRap's British Prusa Mendel, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12905 , was my inspiration for producing this thing, the idea being that it could be scaled as needed and stuck onto other things.
The design was produced with a piece of graph paper, an image downloaded from the internet and my somewhat distant memory of being taught at Cubs that the Union Jack is made up of three flags: the white diagonal cross on a blue background of St. Andrew (Scotland), the red diagonal cross on a white background of St. Patrick (Ireland) and the vertical red cross on a white background of St. George (England). The object is made up of three parts: a white base colour on top of which is a blue colour topped off with red.
The Union Jack by the way should always be displayed, hung, flown the correct way up (as shown in the photograph) as it is not symmetrical - those in the know should never fly it upside down! Edit: My dad pointed out that the red St. Patrick cross is not as it should be. The two red stripes which form each of the diagonals should be offset and not continuous lines as I have drawn. Ho humm - thank you daddy!

Slice and print the WHITE.STL file as normal using white plastic. This will give you a slab which is 0.6mm tall upon which the BLUE and then RED prints go. (On my RepRapPro Huxley sliced using Slic3r with a layer height of 0.3mm, Z goes from 0.3mm to 0.9mm)
BLUE.STL comes next. I used Slic3r to slice this file (again, 0.6mm tall) but took off the skirt and set the Z-offset to 0.9mm so that it would start on top of the white slab. This print will place the blue triangles on top of the white base as well as laying down the St. Patrick and St. George crosses. Use BLUE plastic for this file.
RED.STL finishes the job. Again, using Slic3r, I took off the skirt and set the Z-offset to start the job on top of the blue plastic This file will overlay RED plastic for the St. Patrick and St. George crosses on top of the blue which was printed earlier. One little tip - starting a print with Z significantly higher than 'normal', (in my case 0.3mm), can give problems if your G-Code speed for raising the Z axis is too high for your particular printer. It may be a good idea to take a look at your BLUE and RED G-Code file and reduce the Z feederate for the initial height required by these two prints. The flag can be printed from a single STL file (RedWhiteBlue.STL) but if you go down that route, you will need to split the file into three and change the filament when the Z height goes above the base colour (change from white to blue) and again when the printer has finished the blue section, (change from blue to red). Scropp gives some good instructions in his blog about how to split your G-Code: http://stephen.cropp.co.uk/2012/02/multi-colour-printing/

description.text:
** I think this was my last update on this design. The joints are stronger now, the lid opens up to a 135 degrees angle, there are fillets at the bottom of the drawer, so you won't take long to catch the last resistor, and there's a protection at the back of the drawer, so the resistor legs won't be in the lid's way.

Yes

Yes

.26

20%

Notes:

The lid lock is a little fragile, so never force it, and if possible, print using higher quality. I intend to modify this project, but since I'm using linux, and I don't like FreeCad very much, it may take a while to do some improvements.

While removing the leftovers, I accidentally broke the circular lock of the lid, so please be gentle while finishing it. As you can see, it fits perfectly the resistors. I want to do some improvements on the lid, like better lock, label support and a little separator that fits in the inside walls. Have to do minor tweaks to improve the correct closure and fit of the lid.
Adobe Inventor 2017

This is an holder for HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor. It can be placed top-down.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/NALsEffnnxg" ></iframe>

The Roomba 700 bumper has a rubber coating, but only on the bottom half.
If you have furniture with a bottom space of 6 to 8 cm the Roomba will bump into the furniture full speed because the distance sensors are placed lower and will look below the furniture.
These two strips replace the standard strip that is on top of the Roomba 700 bumper and has a flat surface to put a rubber strip on.

Because of the size you will need a printer with a large building area. Just print the strips and replace the standard strip. Then put a rubber adhesive protection strip on the new printed part.
Because the Replicator has problems printing very small parts i was not able to make snap fittings the printers well, so you can use a small double sided adhesive to lock the strip firmly on the Roomba.
If anyone can make it better fitting, please do. I also attached the Sketchup file.

author: ssimms

description.text:
Update 29.1.2017: I made v2 of the fan duct. This blows more directly to the tip of the nozzle, still missing the heat block.

This is once again a replacement part for Anycubic Kossel delta printer.

Main differences:

  • 30mm fan is closer to print head and in different angle.
  • 30mm fan holder has access hole for 40mm fan screw. (Hole fits screwdriver, not screw).
  • There is 1mm recess for hotend connector nuts, originally screws were barely long enough.

Main dimensions are close to original, so only basic calibration is needed afterwards. It is also compatible with original hotend connector, but requires new fan duct. I included one here.

My original was a bit twisted and rod screw holes were too rough. If you need this for similar reasons, I recommend printing it once with original, then second time with the 1st print. This requires extra work and double calibration, but this part of delta printer needs more precision than most parts.

title: PASCO Centripetal Acceleration Accessory for Rotary Motion Sensor

description.text:
Centripetal acceleration accessory for a rotary motion sensor.
There are three block parts for setting the channel at different angles (10, 15, 20 degrees).
The blocks have an inset where you can place a mass that acts as a counter-balance.
You will need a small ball that is able to roll along the channel, a 3.1 cm diameter mass, Rotary Motion Sensor, and a rod stand.
https://www.pasco.com/prodCatalog/PS/PS-2120_pasport-rotary-motion-sensor/

Attach a block on the axle of a Rotary Motion Sensor.
Attach the channel to the block.
Spin the system up - observe that the ball remains at the top of the channel, and slowly rolls down as the system loses energy.

Place a ball on the channel and spin the system up.

title: Chair Arm Table/Anti-Gravity Remote Control Holder

description.text: OK, OK, So I know Anti-Gravity is a stretch, but I am sure you have all bitched about this before. You are sitting comfortably, all wrapped up in your Snuggie, when Gravity makes itself known. It, without asking permission, grabs your remote control for your TV and sucks it down onto the floor, just out of reach. Now you have to make the decision, do I continue listening the the Kars-4-Kids TV commercial, or do I get my lazy butt up to retrieve the remote and save myself some brain cells, all the while thinking that Gravity really does suck. This little guy is designed to create a pseudo-stable shelf for your remote control so it wont fall out of reach. The flexible sides adjusts to fit most any chair or couch. You can add more links to make it longer or shorter, depending on your immediate needs.

title: Smart bearing block - common lm8uu bearing block replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The new version is available here!:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2752341

10mm version is now available too:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2203593

UPDATE 1:
Due to a little difference between different bearings sizes I will upload different STLs for different bearing models. Most commonly used 623ZZ came first.

UPDATE 2:
Added R2-5ZZ bearing version STLs

UPDATE 3:
Added R2ZZ bearing version STLs

UPDATE 4:
Materials needed (BOM):

  • 3 bearings ( look STL names - there are types of bearing stl is designed for. Third bearing (arm) can be different from two others, but still has to match it's STL.
  • 2x M3x10mm screws, 4xM3 spacers, 2x m3 nuts (main bearing shafts)
  • 1x M3x16mm screw, 2 or 3 M3 spacers, 1x M3 nut (arm bearing shaft)
  • 1x M3x16mm screw, 1x M3 nut (arm mount)
  • 2x M3x20mm screws, 2xM3 nuts (backlash adjust) - can be replaced with one rubber band :)

Hi.

Bearings in my Anet a8 printer was very poor quality. This was lowering the print quality, so I've decided to replace them with something better.

First I have printed bearing blocks instead of the aluminium ones, because they do not fits lm8uu bearings well. This was better, but not excellent.
Then i have tried printed PLA bearings available on thingverse, but it was a failure too.

I saw bearing block then. It is a smart idea, but none of projects available do not fit my needs. So I have decided to make my own model of bearing block.

This model is a lm8uu bearing replacement ( 8mm shaft bearing with block):

  • size is almost the same. It should fit everywhere when original bearing block fits.
  • should fit large amount of bearing models up to 3x8x10mm ( for example 623zz, R2-5ZZ, and lot of others)
  • It has a backlash compensation, so u will never has unwanted clearance between shaft and block
  • backlash compensation can be done both ways - by two m3 screws (with springs too?), or simply by rubber band :P
  • it is far lighter than original one
  • just some cheap small bearings are needed, m3 screws and m3 spacers

Test it and tell me what you thing.

This looks like complicated model to print, but it is quite easy one :).

Notes:

  • This is for 3 bearings, not 4 as on photos.
  • Just print as low layer height as you can.
  • Print very slow.
  • There is a little bridging over there (but very small ones), so cooling fan may be needed.
  • No supports needed

I have not tested it on multiple bearing models so...
IF THIS PROJECT DO NOT FITS YOUR BEARINGS PLEASE TELL ME !! ----

have fun!

description.text:
Goaty McGoatison sets his jaw with grim determination as he opens the large metal door that sits in front of him. As he pulls the handle with a heavy grunt the door swings freely open. As he stares into the dark abyss that is his refrigerator he thoughtfully decides what to eat. If he chooses the Boar Flank Sandwich proceed to [1C], if he chooses the Banana Split Burger proceed to [1B], if he decides to instead slam the door and proceed to eat himself then shut the book, you are dead.

If anyone would like to choose a path, feel free to comment and I will gladly add the next bit of the story

Introducing Watt the Half Truffle! Side Kick to the infamous Goaty McGoatison from a Choose Your Own Adventure some friends and I have been working on. I decided to add some of the story into my DnD campaign so I created the best mini to represent a Half Truffle, Half Otter (half robot in the future), all around great guy Watt McTruffles! Check out his fun loving friend, Goaty McGoaterson ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2637913 ) or Watt's 4e character sheet.

This is intended as sort of a useless desk toy that points at the location of the international space station in the sky. You can also tell it to point at other things, of course. Final goals are to make it fetch TLE data from the internet, and allow the user to wirelessly tell it what to point at. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=brCzEvc-sUg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FkDNPca6eOw

Currently: It's hard coded to point at a specific satellite. There's not enough program memory in arduino 328 to also fetch data from the internet while calculating orbital parameters. I'm using the 28BYJ stepper drivers aka darlington arrays, which means the steppers are really weak. This is only a problem during homing, which can be fixed by just making the homing speed slower. Although weirdly enough the homing seems to work flawlessly after a bit of a warmup period.

Parts Required

Elegoo 28byj stepper motors https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01CP18J4A
Arduino Nano https://www.amazon.com/ATmega328P-Microcontroller-Board-Cable-Arduino/dp/B00NLAMS9C/
RTC https://www.amazon.com/JBtek-DS1307-AT24C32-memory-Arduino/dp/B00UUR8GJU/
opto endstops https://www.amazon.com/SainSmart-Optical-Endstop-Printer-MEGA2560/dp/B00EVOKHPO/
breadboard https://www.amazon.com/microtivity-400-point-Experiment-Breadboard-Jumper/dp/B004RXKWDQ/
random plastite screws https://www.amazon.com/Thread-Rolling-Plastic-Finish-Phillips/dp/B00GDYDCC0/
misc:
steel MIG welding wire (for the endstop triggers)
foil tape
hot glue

Assembly Tips

Sand the inside of the "orbitrack-gear-lower" so it slides smoothly along the shaft in "orbitrack-base-middle". Do the same for "orbitrack-gear-higher". Be careful when attaching the "pointergearv2" so you don't crack the sideways shaft on "orbitrack-gear-higher". I did but it turned out OK, with enough sanding. Turn the gears by hand to make sure they don't stick and turn freely. This required quite a bit of sanding on my part, but it is possible to do!

I used some opto-endstops that I had laying around. You could probably use the ones i've listed above, but I'm not sure they will fit. The endstops are attached by hot glue, though, so you could definitely make it work. The endstops are triggered by foil tape flags attached to steel wires. The steel wires need to be bent around the gears, and so that they interact with the little nubs that stick out the top of the gears. This is somewhat tricky, but luckily MIG welding wire is cheap and springy enough to be perfect for this application.

I used the box that the 28byj motors came in as the case. Six plastite screws are used to attach the mechanism to that box.

Wiring

In my wiring photo you'll see a lot of stuff, most of it is not used for the functionality described (eg, pointing at space ships). I wanted to obtain data from the internet, and the code is there to do that, but the 328 simply can't handle it. That said, all you need to drive the pointer is a real time clock and the motor drivers. Use the wiring diagram (such as it is) to hook it up exactly as I've done. You definitely don't need to do it exactly like this, but that's what I did.

1/19/2017 UPDATE
actually the motors are much more reliable if you plug their +5V into the arduino's +5V pin, if you are powering it via USB. I thought the Vin was the +5 USB voltage, but it isn't, and in fact is only used for external power.

What you need in addition:

  • 1x GT2 toothed idler with:

    18mm outer diameter
    9mm thickness
  • 1x M5 screw (>16mm)
  • 1x M5 nut
  • 2x M4 30mm screws
  • 2x M4 nuts

for further information read the readme of the original tensioner

author: drumfire

description.text:
My math students often have trouble focusing in study hall. One of the students came to class with a fidget/hand_spinner. As someone with ADHD, I find twirling a pen or tapping my foot a much better alternative to opioids or focus enhancing drugs. I thought that having my students design their own spinner would be a great exercise in learning geometric construction through 123D Design, Autocad's basic 3D modeling software, and (hopefully) enhance focus in the classroom. Here is my take on the triangular hand_spinner with central axis rotation. I used 4 608zz 8227 skateboard bearings. Picked them up for a couple of bucks on Amazon.

*update: I printed my spinner. It works well! Disclaimer, I have fairly large hands so the spinner, which is designed for me, will be slightly bigger than it would normally. But, you can simply edit the part by bringing each of the three outer bearing cut outs closer to the center and that should make a smaller spinner.

author: kelticsylk

print_settings.Notes:: I designed it so that there's minimal bridging, it should print well with on most printers.

description.text:
Now New and Improved!

I've updated this thing to now be angled slightly downwards, as well as making the opening a proper air nozzle to give the best flow. Additionally, I increased the contact between the fan output and the fan duct to make it a better seal and eliminate wasteful airflow.

I additionally made changes to the design to allow it to be printed in vase mode! Just make sure you enable 5+ top solid layers for best results.

Summary

I've been having trouble finding a fan duct I really like, I found a rear facing fan duct on here but it just didn't suit my purposes. This is technically a remix, however I designed it without using the original as reference so also technically not. There are 4 variations:

  • A wide version for dual extrusion printing
  • A version that only points toward the right nozzle
  • A version that only points toward the left nozzle

Requires a 12v 50mm x 15mm radial fan that may have been included with your printer (it was included with my Powerspec 3D Ultra)

Simply snap the fan in place, and then snap it onto your extruder gantry. It will be a tight fit, but it will indeed fit onto gantry.

title: tritium glow stick printable Parabollic enclosure

description.text:
This is parabollic enclosure for tritium glowstick to make the light more directed and intense.
You will get more light than with simple glowstick enclosure.

Pause it on top of internal cavity, insert glowstick, fill it with rubbery transparent glue, unpause to print it over. cover the curved side with aluminium foil.

i used "Betalight Tritium Self Illumination Grow Marker Isotope 3.5mm 25mm Green 1pc" from Ebay - US $15.50

I used PETG trnasparent.
MAX infill
insert pause to top layer of the cavity or pause it yourself to insert the glow stick.
fill it with rubbery transparentglue to dampen impacts

post processing

glue the curved part (and sides) with reflective material like aluminium foil, polish the flat side (if you don't have a PEI on the bed) and drill a hole for keyring.

I didn't use support on Chili_Hottest, but you might want it for the chili stem. Mine turned out okAY.

You will need supports for Chili_Creative.

Chili_Best will print without support.
Depending on color choice, you might need to give the letters a quick paint job so they stand out.

I used Autodesk Inventor to make the bases and emboss the text on each base. Chili_Best was created solely in Inventor.

The flames were drawn in AutoCAD and converted to stl's in Inventor.

For Chili_Hottest and Chili_Creative, I exported the bases from Inventor as stl's and combined everything using Meshmixer.

Voilà c'est fait !!
Tout d'abord un grand merci à l 'auteur du projet ! LtDan!
J'ai redessiné la plupart des pièces sous solidworks pour pouvoir les imprimer sans support( qui posent problème à bon nombre d'entre nous et pour un travail plus propre et précis).
L'ensemble fonctionne très bien ,ayant réduit certaines dimensions ( jeu ). Ça reste un magnifique jouet !Se déplace sur sol lisse sinon c'est la chute.
Petite video https://youtu.be/Hbf4bzpnZiw
seconde video https://youtu.be/x_ZSA21_KO0
une autre https://youtu.be/CpWqwVhXS4o
J'ai gardé le design de l'auteur sans en faire plus.(pas le temps pour les détails)
Les deux corps sont assemblés par trois vis M3 x 40 mm et le body est juste posé sur l'ensemble.
Le moteur est un 100 tr/min http://www.ebay.fr/itm/W6-JA12-N20-Model-DC-12V-100RPM-Torque-Gearbox-Micro-Gear-Box-Motor-Silver-Gold-/182327025370?hash=item2a73899eda:g:5l4AAOSwnbZYDbnD que l'on peut trouver pour max 4 euros sur ebay ,cdiscount...
J'imprime avec brim en 0.2mm à 205 degrés puis je diminue à 195 °,le lit entre 60 ° et 65 °, j'utilise de la laque de grande surface pour moi impératif et gage de qualité.

Bon nombre de pièces sont assemblées par colle.
Bien faire attention aux pièces miroirs,servez vous du pdf de LtDan et des nombreuses photos.
J'espère que mes photos ,fichiers,et l'immense travail de l'auteur vous permettrons d'arriver à terme.
J'utilise REPETIER.

enjoy yourselves!

title: Exeggaratetd Filamentguide Anet A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
English:
Since I have mounted the spool of my prusa i3 clone to the wooden plate, the filament has to be guided upwards to the extruder. Thats why I designed this movable filament guide. sure it looks a little bit exaggerated, but I like it. To get this thing together you'll need theese parts:
2x M3x5
3x M3x30
6x washer M3
2x M3 nut
1x M8x40
1x M8x30
2x nut M8
3x washer M8
2 bearings 22mm outer diameter

Deutsch:
Da ich meine Filamentspule am Anet A8 auf der Holzplatte montiert habe muss das Filament in einem Bogen zum Extruder geführt werden. Deshalb hab ich diese bewegliche Filamentführung entworfen und auf den Prusa i3-Klon geschraubt. Sieht etwas übertrieben aus, aber mir gefällts. Für den Zusammenbau braucht man noch diverse Teile aus der Schraubenkiste und zwei Kugellager (22mm Aussendurchmesser).
2x M3x5
3x M3x30
6x Unterlegscheibe M3
2x M3 Mutter
1x M8x40
1x M8x30
2x Mutter M8
3x Unterlegscheibe M8

https://youtu.be/RX8w7NqVoxE

author: froetz

title: Upgraded clip for 200mm round build plate

description.text:
This design is loosely based on Thinner42's glass clamp.

It fits on an AnyCubic Kossel delta printer with a 200mm diameter print bed. It should work on any printer that uses extruded 2020 aluminum as a frame. These clips hold the glass very securely and don't allow for any movement.

You will need the following for each clip:
3 x M4x8mm
3 x M4 square nut.

(For all 3 clips you will need 9 of each)

I have had succes sprinting this design without any support. There is one small hollow in the larger component, but my printer was able to print it.

description.text:
Printed as I wanted a custom door handle for the cupboards that contain our cleaning supplies.

Once printed they need tapping with a M5 tap and then an M5 bolt can be used to secure them to the door.

I do have a model with an M5 thread in it, but its not working correctly at the moment. I will refine it and upload once completed.

When printing, I found it best to lie the model down so the cylinder is pointing up in the Z-axis. Then It didn't sag whilst printing, and less support required.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

When printing, I found it best to lie the model down so the cylinder is pointing up in the Z-axis. Then It didn't sag whilst printing, and less support required.

description.text:

The openscad file is also present if you need to do some adjustments.

The latest files are available of my github repository: https://github.com/clementleger/3d_parts
